title: Corrections & Amplifications
text:
The New York State Department of Financial Services fined Barclays PLC in 2018 over then-Chief Executive Jes Staley's efforts to unmask a whistleblower. A Page One article on Tuesday about Mr. Staley's resignation incorrectly said that U.S. authorities fined Mr. Staley over the episode. The error also appeared in Business & Finance articles about Barclays on Feb. 14, 2020, and Feb. 26, 2020.

(See: "Barclays CEO Out As U.K. Questions Candor on Epstein --- Regulators conclude Staley misrepresented his association with the convicted sex offender" -- WSJ November 2, 2021; "U.K. Probes Barclays Chief's Ties to Epstein" -- WSJ February 14, 2020; "Banking & Finance: Activist Criticizes Barclays's Governance" -- WSJ February 26, 2020)

---

Doctoral student Dennis Hu studied software engineering as an undergraduate. A World News article on Wednesday about U.S. visa requirements for Chinese students incorrectly said computer science.

(See: "World News: U.S. Visa Bans Called Harmful --- Universities, research institutes say Trump's China-student curbs put innovation at risk" -- WSJ November 3, 2021)

---

The Bank of Canada said it would end quantitative easing and could raise its benchmark overnight interest rate sooner than it previously anticipated. A Business & Finance article on Monday about the narrowing gap between shorter- and longer-term Treasury yields incorrectly said the Bank of Canada brought an end to broad-based emergency-income benefits for households and businesses, which are Canadian government policies.

(See: "Narrow Yield Gap Shows Worries on Rates, Growth" -- WSJ November 1, 2021)

---

Activision Blizzard Inc.'s full-year outlook for net bookings is $8.65 billion. In some editions Wednesday, a Business News article about the company incorrectly gave the figure as $8.56 billion.

---

Netflix Inc. removed episodes of licensed political thriller "Pine Gap" in the Philippines several weeks ago. A World Watch article on Wednesday about the episodes incorrectly said Netflix removed them this week.

(See: "World News: World Watch" -- WSJ November 3, 2021)

---

American Airlines Group Inc. is based in Fort Worth, Texas. A Business & Finance article on Tuesday about the airline incorrectly said it is based in Dallas.

(See: "American Cancels More Flights" -- WSJ November 2, 2021)

---

Notice to readers: Some Wall Street Journal staff members are working remotely during the pandemic. Please send reader comments only by email or phone, using the contacts below, not via U.S. Mail.

---

Readers can alert The Wall Street Journal to any errors in news articles by e-mailing wsjcontact@wsj.com or by calling 888-410-2667.
